title: English Grammar (Basic Tenses)
description: Test your knowledge of basic English tenses.

questions.questionText: Which of the following sentences is in the present continuous tense?
questions.explanation: The present continuous tense is used to describe actions happening right now or in the near future.

questions.questionText: Which sentence is in the past perfect tense?
questions.explanation: The past perfect tense is used to describe an action that was completed before another action in the past.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is the correct sentence in future tense?
questions.explanation: The future tense is used to describe actions that will happen in the future.

questions.questionText: Choose the correct sentence in the present perfect tense.
questions.explanation: The present perfect tense is used for actions that occurred at an unspecified time before now.

questions.questionText: Which sentence is in the past continuous tense?
questions.explanation: The past continuous tense is used for actions that were happening at a specific point in the past.

title: English Grammar (Parts of Speech)
description: Test your knowledge of parts of speech in English grammar.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is a noun?
questions.explanation: A noun is a word that represents a person, place, thing, or idea.

questions.questionText: Which word is an adjective in the sentence: 'She has a beautiful dress.'?
questions.explanation: An adjective is a word that describes or modifies a noun.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is a verb?
questions.explanation: A verb is a word that describes an action or state of being.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is an adverb?
questions.explanation: An adverb modifies a verb, adjective, or another adverb. 'Slowly' modifies the verb 'running'.

questions.questionText: In the sentence 'She gave me the book,' what part of speech is 'book'?
questions.explanation: A noun is a word that identifies a person, place, thing, or idea. 'Book' is a thing.

title: English Grammar (Subject-Verb Agreement)
description: Test your understanding of subject-verb agreement in English.

questions.questionText: Choose the correct sentence:
options: She go to school every day.
She goes to school every day.
She going to school every day.
She to go to school every day.
questions.correctOption: She goes to school every day.
questions.explanation: In subject-verb agreement, the subject 'she' is singular, so the verb 'goes' should be used.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is correct?
questions.explanation: In subject-verb agreement, 'dogs' is plural, so the verb should be 'run' (without 's').

questions.explanation: The correct form is 'doesn't' for singular subjects in the present tense.

title: English Grammar (Sentence Structure)
description: Learn about the basic sentence structures in English grammar.

questions.questionText: Which sentence is in the passive voice?
options: The mouse was chased by the cat.
The cat is chasing the mouse.
The mouse is chasing the cat.
questions.correctOption: The mouse was chased by the cat.
questions.explanation: In the passive voice, the object of the action becomes the subject of the sentence.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is a simple sentence?
options: I went to the store and bought milk.
Although I was tired, I went to the store.
I went to the store but forgot to buy milk.
questions.explanation: A simple sentence consists of only one independent clause with a subject and predicate.

questions.questionText: Which sentence is a compound sentence?
options: She is reading a book, and he is watching TV.
She reads the book every day.
questions.correctOption: She is reading a book, and he is watching TV.
questions.explanation: A compound sentence contains two independent clauses joined by a conjunction.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is a complex sentence?
options: Because I was tired, I went to bed early.
questions.correctOption: Because I was tired, I went to bed early.
questions.explanation: A complex sentence contains one independent clause and one or more dependent clauses.

questions.questionText: Which sentence is a question?
options: You are coming to the party.
Are you coming to the party?
You will come to the party.
questions.correctOption: Are you coming to the party?
questions.explanation: A question sentence starts with an auxiliary verb or question word.

title: English Grammar (Punctuation)
description: Test your knowledge of punctuation marks in English.

questions.questionText: Which sentence is correctly punctuated?
questions.explanation: In direct speech, the punctuation should be inside the quotation marks.

questions.questionText: Choose the sentence with correct punctuation:
options: The cat, who was hungry, ate the food.
The cat who was hungry ate the food.
The cat who was hungry, ate the food.
The cat who, was hungry ate the food.
questions.correctOption: The cat, who was hungry, ate the food.
questions.explanation: Non-essential clauses should be set off with commas.

questions.questionText: Which sentence uses the semicolon correctly?
options: I like to read; and I love to write.
I like to read, I love to write.
I like to read; I love to write.
I like to read: I love to write.
questions.correctOption: I like to read; I love to write.
questions.explanation: A semicolon is used to connect closely related independent clauses.

questions.questionText: Which sentence is correctly punctuated?
options: It's raining outside, don't forget your umbrella.
It's raining outside don't forget your umbrella.
It's raining outside; don't forget your umbrella.
It's raining outside, don't forget; your umbrella.
questions.correctOption: It's raining outside; don't forget your umbrella.
questions.explanation: A semicolon is used here to link two related clauses.

questions.questionText: Which sentence correctly uses the apostrophe?
questions.explanation: The apostrophe is used to show possession.
